elements.text:
The future value
of ₹100 it
depreciates at 30%
elements.originalText:
The future value
of ₹100 it
depreciates at 30%

elements.text:
The future value
of ₹100 if it
appreciates at 30%
elements.originalText:
The future value
of ₹100 if it
appreciates at 30%

elements.text:
The future value
of ₹100 if they
cancel out
elements.originalText:
The future value
of ₹100 if they
cancel out

elements.text:
If ₹100 of money undergoes inflation at 30%
(i.e. depreciates at 30%), then the future market value of
₹100 is ₹70 and vice versa, the present market value of
₹70 is ₹100. So, to maintain a PRESENT MARKET VALUE
of ₹100 till the future, an asset having a present market value of ₹100
would have to grow to a future market value of ₹130.
And what's worth a future market value of ₹130?
The face value ₹130! This higher market value of ₹130 would
cancel out the supposed depreciation to a market value of ₹70.
Hence, we maintain the present market value of ₹100 into the future.
elements.originalText:
If ₹100 of money undergoes inflation at 30%
(i.e. depreciates at 30%), then the future market value of
₹100 is ₹70 and vice versa, the present market value of
₹70 is ₹100. So, to maintain a PRESENT MARKET VALUE
of ₹100 till the future, an asset having a present market value of ₹100
would have to grow to a future market value of ₹130.
And what's worth a future market value of ₹130?
The face value ₹130! This higher market value of ₹130 would
cancel out the supposed depreciation to a market value of ₹70.
Hence, we maintain the present market value of ₹100 into the future.

elements.text:
Points to keep in mind:
- Present value is short for "present market value" and future value
is short for the "future market value"
- At any given point in time, the market value of money is
equal to its face value. Across time however, this is no longer true.
